image.altText: Joe Biden sits at his Oval Office desk and speaks.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden makes a rare prime-time national address in which he asks congress for more support for Israel and Ukraine, saying the world is "facing an inflection point in history". Follow live.

title.children: 'Facing inflection point': Biden gives rare prime-time address in bid for Ukraine, Israel funds

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are explosions audible in the cramped, humid room where Azmi Keshawi shelters with his family in Gaza's southern city of Khan Younis. The bombardments keep coming closer, he says, and they're wreaking death and destruction. Mr Keshawi, his wife, two sons, two daughters and tiny grandchildren are trying to survive inside. They get drinking water in jerrycans from the UN school. It tastes salty. The desalination stations stopped working when the fuel ran out. "How the hell did the entire world just watch and let Israel turn off the water?" says Mr Keshawi, 59, a US-educated researcher at the International Crisis Group, his voice rising with anger. The nights are the hardest, he says. When airstrikes crash nearby and explosions light up the sky, the adults muster what little resolve they have to soothe the children. "Boom!" they yell and cheer when the bombs thunder. The babies laugh. But older kids are terrified. "It's really killing me," Mr Keshawi says. "It really breaks my heart." AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Life in Gaza's shelters: 'How the hell did the entire world just watch?'

children.content: There are explosions audible in the cramped, humid room where Azmi Keshawi shelters with his family in Gaza's southern city of Khan Younis.

props.alt: Aerial shot of rows of white tents

children.content: (AP Photo: Fatima Shbair)
The bombardments keep coming closer, he says, and they're wreaking death and destruction.
Mr Keshawi, his wife, two sons, two daughters and tiny grandchildren are trying to survive inside.
They get drinking water in jerrycans from the UN school. It tastes salty. The desalination stations stopped working when the fuel ran out.
"How the hell did the entire world just watch and let Israel turn off the water?" says Mr Keshawi, 59, a US-educated researcher at the International Crisis Group, his voice rising with anger.
The nights are the hardest, he says.
When airstrikes crash nearby and explosions light up the sky, the adults muster what little resolve they have to soothe the children.
"Boom!" they yell and cheer when the bombs thunder. The babies laugh. But older kids are terrified.

props.alt: A woman stands with two children inside a white tent

children.content: (AP Photo: Fatima Shbair)
"It's really killing me," Mr Keshawi says. "It really breaks my heart."
AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden doesn't do this often. A prime-time television address to the nation gives the commander in chief a direct line to the homes of ordinary Americans (hoping that they're still watching broadcast or cable television instead of streaming something). He kept his language simple. Attempting to explain why Americans should both care about wars being fought far away and be willing to help fund them. His message was pretty simple – if America doesn't help fight Ukraine and Israel defend themselves now, then it'll create greater problem later. "History has taught us that when terrorists don't pay a price for their terror, when dictators don't pay a price for their aggression, they cause more chaos and death and more destruction," he said. The United States has sent Ukraine $US60 billion in funding and equipment through military, economic, and humanitarian aid. Israel is the biggest recipient of US foreign aid, being given nearly $US160 billion before this latest outbreak of violence. It's expected the latest request will be for tens of billions more. For Americans who've had to battle through a period of high inflation, it's understandable that many would start to question why America has to foot the bill for foreign conflicts. Mr Biden will hope that his 15 minute speech will convince them that it's money well spent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Analysis: Biden attempts to convince Americans billions on Ukraine, Israel is well spent

children.content: US President Joe Biden doesn't do this often.

A prime-time television address to the nation gives the commander in chief a direct line to the homes of ordinary Americans (hoping that they're still watching broadcast or cable television instead of streaming something).
He kept his language simple.
Attempting to explain why Americans should both care about wars being fought far away and be willing to help fund them.
His message was pretty simple – if America doesn't help fight Ukraine and Israel defend themselves now, then it'll create greater problem later.
"History has taught us that when terrorists don't pay a price for their terror, when dictators don't pay a price for their aggression, they cause more chaos and death and more destruction," he said.
The United States has sent Ukraine
$US60 billion
in funding and equipment through military, economic, and humanitarian aid.
Israel is the biggest recipient of US foreign aid, being given nearly $US160 billion before this latest outbreak of violence.
It's expected the latest request will be for tens of billions more.
For Americans who've had to battle through a period of high inflation, it's understandable that many would start to question why America has to foot the bill for foreign conflicts.
Mr Biden will hope that his 15 minute speech will convince them that it's money well spent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden knows that while funding for Israel remains popular across party lines (there are some progressive Democrats who are increasingly outspoken in their support of the Palestinian cause but they remain a small minority) there is an increasingly large group of Republican politicians who have expressed concerns about the tens of billions of dollars that Ukraine has already received. By requesting money for both at the same time, he hopes to limit the chance of those Republicans from trying to knock back the request. Let's see if it works.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Analysis: Joe Biden wants to clearly link Israel and Ukraine funding

children.content: US President
Joe Biden

knows that while funding for Israel remains popular across party lines (there are some progressive Democrats who are increasingly outspoken in their support of the Palestinian cause but they remain a small minority) there is an increasingly large group of Republican politicians who have expressed concerns about the tens of billions of dollars that Ukraine has already received.
By requesting money for both at the same time, he hopes to limit the chance of those Republicans from trying to knock back the request. Let's see if it works.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Insignia Financial's chief executive Renato Mota will step down after 20 years with the company. Mr Mota says it's been a privilege to lead the company for the past five years. "Having established a clear path for the next three years, I feel this is the right inflection point to provide the business with fresh perspective to continue the journey." Shares fell as much as 15% in this morning's trade to $1.99, reaching its lowest level since 2009. Insignia was formerly known as IOOF Financial.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shares in Australia's Insignia Financial hit 14-year low

children.content: Insignia Financial's chief executive
Renato Mota will step down after 20 years with the company.
Mr Mota says it's been a privilege to lead the company for the past five years.
"Having established a clear path for the next three years, I feel this is the right inflection point to provide the business with fresh perspective to continue the journey."
Shares fell as much as 15% in this morning's trade to $1.99, reaching its lowest level since 2009.
Insignia was formerly known as IOOF Financial.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Michelle Bullock and assistant governor Christopher Kent are scheduled for testimony at the Senate Economics Legislation Committee next Thursday. The hearing will provide a better indication of whether the Reserve Bank will raise rates on Melbourne Cup Day. The September-quarter CPI data, due for release on Wednesday, will also feed into the decision. Most economists are expecting annual inflation to continue easing from 6 per cent in the June quarter to somewhere between 5 per cent and 5.4 per cent. Current market pricing has the odds of a November interest rate rise by the Reserve Bank at about 25 per cent. But an inflation number above those forecasts would raise the chance of another rate hike in the lead-up to the Christmas holidays.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is the RBA likely to raise rates on Cup Day?

children.content: RBA governor Michelle Bullock and assistant governor Christopher Kent are scheduled for testimony at the Senate Economics Legislation Committee next Thursday.
The hearing will provide a better indication of whether the Reserve Bank will raise rates on Melbourne Cup Day.
The September-quarter CPI data, due for release on Wednesday, will also feed into the decision.
Most economists are expecting annual inflation to continue easing from 6 per cent in the June quarter to somewhere between 5 per cent and 5.4 per cent.
Current market pricing has the odds of a November interest rate rise by the Reserve Bank at about 25 per cent.
But an inflation number above those forecasts would raise the chance of another rate hike in the lead-up to the Christmas holidays.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The share price of Australian lithium developer Liontown Resources has tanked this morning, down as much as 35%. It's all because yesterday it announced a billion-dollar funding package for its flagship Kathleen Valley lithium project, planning to raise $376 million in a discounted share placement and $760 million via debt. Funding plans had to change because earlier in the week US-based Albemarle Corp withdrew its $6.6 billion buyout bid, citing 'growing complexities.' The withdrawal came days after Hancock Prospecting (Gina Rinehart's company!) raised its stake to 19.9% of Liontown (which would have been enough to block the Albemarle bid of $3 per share). The Kathleen Valley project is widely regarded as one of the world's top five lithium projects, and Liontown has already signed deals to supply Ford Motor and Tesla. Here's a chart showing you Liontown's shareprice over the last 10 days. Talk about a slide!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is going on with Liontown Resources?
